speaker: Elena
text: So the entire post-war economic order, the one that lifted billions out of poverty, was just a 'forty-year aberration'? That's a rather sweeping dismissal, James.

speaker: James
text: [dry] Sweeping, perhaps, but the evidence for its unsustainability became rather stark, wouldn't you say? Especially when you can't make your own surgical masks.

speaker: Elena
text: COVID exposed vulnerabilities, absolutely. But what about the geopolitical necessity of binding allies after 1945? That wasn't an 'aberration,' it was a strategic masterstroke.

speaker: James
text: A masterstroke that ultimately hollowed out your industrial base and left you reliant on rivals. The article calls it a 'strategic subsidy'.

speaker: Elena
text: I take your point on dependencies. But the article frames this return as pure mercantilism. Is it really that simple?

speaker: James
text: Hamilton's principles were identical: protect infant industries, secure national sovereignty. The language is different, but the substance is the same.

speaker: Elena
text: But Germany's current talk of 'strategic autonomy' or the EU's Chips Act feels defensive, not aggressive like historical mercantilism.

speaker: James
text: [sardonic] Defensive often looks a lot like aggressive when you're on the receiving end. Friedrich List called free trade 'kicking away the ladder' for a reason.

speaker: Elena
text: He argued Britain preached free trade only after it had industrialised. So, hypocrisy then?

speaker: James
text: Indeed. And China has simply learned from the best. They moved up the value chain precisely by not playing by the rules the West set for everyone else.

speaker: Elena
text: That's a direct link to our 'China Has Many Of The Characteristics Of An Emerging Colonial Power' discussion. They applied mercantilist principles to great effect.

speaker: James
text: Exactly. They didn't stick to cheap toys. Now they dominate everything from solar panels to EVs.

speaker: Elena
text: The sheer strategic vulnerability is undeniable. Europe pledged a million artillery shells to Ukraine. They couldn't meet the target.

speaker: James
text: [emphatic] Precisely. Europe's GDP is ten times Russia's, but its industrial capacity for defence is a fraction. That's the real cost.

speaker: Elena
text: It's shocking. We discussed it in 'Europe Rearms' â€“ the continent simply forgot how to produce the basics for defence.

speaker: James
text: And for medicine, during COVID. Basic pharmaceuticals from China. The richest nation dependent on its adversary.

speaker: Elena
text: Okay, that's a hard point to argue with.

speaker: James
text: The article suggests technology is also enabling this return. AI and robotics eliminate the labour cost advantage of offshoring.

speaker: Elena
text: So the factories return, but not the jobs? That's the 'Robotics and Slavery' paradox right there.

speaker: James
text: Some jobs will change, yes. But manufacturing creates a virtuous cycle: skills, innovation, new industries.

speaker: Elena
text: I worry about the social cost for communities, though. Those 2.5 million reshored jobs since 2010 are good, but what happens when automation takes over?

speaker: James
text: [thoughtful] That's a valid concern. The transition needs careful management. But the alternative was strategic impotence.

speaker: Elena
text: True. The Rome analogy in the article is... actually devastating. Outsourcing military and agriculture led to its fall.

speaker: James
text: It's not about being poor. It's about control over your essential goods and capabilities. Or lack thereof.

speaker: Elena
text: [conceding] Okay, fine. I'll give you that. Relying on others for basics is a path to decline. It's a brutal truth.

speaker: James
text: So we're returning to something resembling nineteenth-century industrial policy. Tariffs, subsidies, state-directed investment.

speaker: Elena
text: Under new names: 'friend-shoring,' 'resilience,' 'strategic autonomy.' It's still mercantilism.

speaker: James
text: The language shifts, but the underlying historical forces don't. The rules always applied.

speaker: Elena
text: I still struggle with the idea that free trade was *purely* an aberration. It did bring global prosperity for a time.

speaker: James
text: [clipped] It brought prosperity for *some* and vulnerability for *others*. The 'Crisis: Or An Explanation On The Origins Of The Decline Of The West' showed the long-term cost.

speaker: Elena
text: So the US-Taiwan deal isn't just about semiconductors. It's about rebuilding a specific kind of global order, not just profit.

speaker: James
text: Precisely. It's about national sovereignty and security.

speaker: Elena
text: [thoughtful] I suppose I hadn't fully appreciated the scale of that strategic trade-off. It was a bargain, but the cost has become existential.

speaker: James
text: [amused] Like Marlowe's Doctor Faustus. Trading long-term security for short-term gain.

speaker: Elena
text: Yes, exactly. And the devil is now collecting.

speaker: James
text: The question is, can the West build fast enough?

speaker: Elena
text: I think that's the real challenge. The political will is there, but rebuilding the capacity and skills... that's much harder to just magic back.
